entry.title: [CW] A small update on the Ukraine war front - it appears that the sanctions Lithuani
entry.content:
A small update on the Ukraine war front - it appears that the sanctions Lithuania put on Kalingrad are [now facing pressure from an EU commission](https://statefirstnews.com/2022/07/13/update-today-breakingthe-european-commission-today-backed-down-to-russian-threats-and-issued-new-guidelines-saying-sanctions-dont-apply-to-rail-transit-via-lithuania-to-kaliningrad-th/). The EU wants Lithuania to back down. It would seem that predictions that Russia saw this move as a serious threat to its sovereignty over Kalingrad were correct. I was more surprised that the EU decided to fold that quickly. When they're already getting Russia to shut down Nord Stream 2 and other pipelines, it makes me wonder what cards are left to play.
While I do find the Ukranian case for war sympathetic, I really don't get the case for Lithuania poking the bear here. This isn't even a case of Lithuania building up a military capable of enforcing the regulations it was trying to pass, just taking an opportunity to swipe at the much bigger country next door for unclear reasons. Who benefits?
